title: Why Manchester United want to sign Juventus star Mario Mandzukic
text:
Manchester United are set to move for Mario Mandzukic in January (Picture: Getty)

Manchester United boss Ole Gunnar Solskjaer is ready to break his own transfer policy to sign Juventus forward Mario Mandzukic amid concerns his long-term targets will be unattainable come January, Metro.co.uk understands.

The Red Devils made a late move for the 33-year-old in the summer but they were beaten by the clock and failed to get a deal over the line.

Solskjaer’s decision to offload Romelu Lukaku and Alexis Sanchez without signing a replacement has backfired and his United side have scored more than one goal in a match on a solitary occasion this term, and that came in a 4-0 win against Chelsea on the opening weekend of the season.

Mandzukic, meanwhile, was not entirely convinced by a move to Old Trafford and he decided to stay in Turin as he was confident of keeping his place under new boss Maurizio Sarri. However, Sarri has favoured Gonzalo Higuain and Mandzukic is yet to play a single minute under the former Chelsea boss.

Mandzukic is yet to feature for Juventus this season (Picture: Getty)

United opened a dialogue with Juventus over Mandzukic when the Serie A giants made a move of their own for Lukaku but the Belgian was determined to move to Inter Milan to work with Antonio Conte.

Advertisement

Nevertheless, United have maintained their interest in the veteran and their troubles in front of goal have only reinforced Solskjaer’s desire to strengthen his attack in January.

While Mandzukic would clearly provide some much-needed depth in attacking areas, he hasn’t managed double figures in terms of league goals since the 2015/16 campaign and at 33 years of age the club would only be prepared to hand him an 18-month deal at most.

The move is out of line with the transfer policy Solskjaer adopted last summer when he targeted young, hungry British players that could develop in years to come. But while Solskjaer’s young side are not exactly light on experience, they’re lacking in know-how and few strikers on the market possess Mandzukic’s temperament or pedigree.

Mandzukic's record at Juventus - all competitions 2015/16: Appearances 36, Goals 13

2016/17: Appearances 50, Goals 11

2017/18: Appearances 43, Goals 10

2018/19: Appearances 33, Goals 10

Another key element is Solskjaer’s acknowledgement that United’s playing style will not change overnight.

The Norwegian has dispensed with former Jose Mourinho allies such as Marouane Fellaini, Ander Herrera and Lukaku as he tries to implement a new brand of football at Old Trafford but United’s struggles in front of goal prove they’ve found the transition difficult. Since Solskjaer’s appointment in March, United have managed 16 goals in 15 league games.

Mandzukic, like Lukaku, is strong in the air, but plying him with crosses would not represent United’s plan A ,with the Croatian instead providing back-up to Anthony Martial and Marcus Rashford. That way, Solskjaer feels he can help bridge the gap as United transition to a new style of play, while at the same time refusing to sacrifice his own ideals.

At the forefront of Solskjaer’s thinking, however, is his growing acceptance that United are increasingly unlikely to be able to attract his long-term targets this winter.

Advertisement

United wanted Jadon Sancho last summer but their failure to qualify for the Champions League ended all hopes of signing the Dortmund star. Instead of targeting another right winger, Solskjaer decided to work with what he had in the hope that the club could revisit a move for Sancho in 2020.

But there are only so many areas of an ailing team that Solskjaer can ignore without turning to short-term fixes.

Moussa Dembele is a target for United (Picture: Getty)

United are interested in former Celtic striker Moussa Dembele but Lyon are tough negotiators and are unlikely to allow the Frenchman to leave midway through the season. Ousmane Dembele, the Barcelona winger, is another target but he’d have far more attractive offers than Old Trafford should the Catalans decide to let him leave.

With long-term targets unavailable, Solskjaer is willing to compromise but it remains to be seen whether Mandzukic will take up the club’s offer.

Juventus were seeking between £9-11m for the Croatian last summer but his lack of playing time under Sarri, combined with the club’s growing wage bill, means they will accept a far smaller fee in January.

Mandzukic is now minded to leave Juventus but he has lucrative offers on the table from Qatar and America. The forward is 34 in May and is wary that his next contract could be his last in football.
